content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the vector-valued function defined by <math alttext="f of t, equals, open angled bracket, 3 t, plus t squared, comma 6, t minus t cubed, close angled bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⟩</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is <math alttext="f prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="the negative of the fraction 22 over 25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="open angled bracket, 7 comma negative 6, close angled bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mo>⟩</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="open angled bracket, 10 comma 4, close angled bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>⟩</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="open angled bracket, 7 comma negative 6, close angled bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mo>⟩</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.4: (BC ONLY) Defining and Differentiating Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
